An aspiring Disney Chef from Schalmont is the recipient of an award and scholarship from SUNY SCCC thanks to his hard work and perseverance at Capital Region BOCES Career and Technical School.

Alec Walsh received the Tech Prep Award from Schenectady County Community College during a virtual graduation ceremony at the end of June.

A two-year culinary student at BOCES, Walsh spent his last year in the honors-level Culinary Tech Prep program where he earned college credits from SUNY SCCC while perfecting culinary skills ranging from menu design to pastry preparation.

Walsh said he enjoys the creativity and the sense of fulfillment he gets from cooking.

“I like seeing a product go from start to finish. I enjoy the hands-on aspects of the program,” he said.

As to his future, Walsh said, “I want to one-day work for Disney in the culinary department. I enjoy the hands-on aspects of the program.”

Jake Olsen and his classmates in the Capital Region BOCES Career and Technical School Construction/Heavy Equipment program are building solid foundations to build financially lucrative careers.

Olsen, a junior from Schalmont, is one of about four-dozen students in the two-year Construction/Heavy Equipment Program on the Schoharie Capital Region BOCES Career and Technical School campus this school year. He and other students in the program learn the knowledge and skills required to enter the construction and equipment operator industries or pursue further education in college or technical school. They learn everything from equipment operator and maintenance skills to how to construct a building while earning National Center for Construction Education and Research (NCCER) certifications, which are recognized nationwide by contractors and employers, as well as OSHA and first aid certifications.

An update about absentee ballot delivery/pick up:
Our district, along with others across the State, has been informed that delays in ballot deliveries are expected. Schalmont voters should receive ballots via mail by this Saturday, June 6th. That said, voters are welcome to visit our district office (located on the high school campus) to pick up a ballot on Friday, June 5th from 8am-4pm and Monday, June 8th from 8am-5pm.

Information regarding absentee ballot return:
Completed ballots must be received by 5pm on Tuesday, June 9th. They may be returned by mail but to ensure submission by this deadline, voters are also able to drop their completed ballots off at the district office (a mail slot is available). Other drop off locations include a locked, secured drop box at the Jefferson Elementary School parent entrance and a locked, secured drop box at the main entrance of the Woestina School in Rotterdam Junction. Please contact the district office at (518) 355-9200 ext. 4002 if you have any questions or need assistance. We appreciate your patience and support.

The Lake Placid Winter Olympics 40 year anniversary was recently celebrated in Lake Placid NY, and on Friday February 28th, Ms. Gandrow's Algebra 1 students experienced the Dimensional Analysis Olympics. Students competed in a variety of events including Speed Walking, Jumping Rope, the Broad Jump, Bouncing Balls, The Starburst, Hop till you Drop, and For the Love of Chocolate, where students had to participate, record data and convert measurements to answer questions pertaining to the event. For example in Speed Walking, students had to measure the length of the hall in meters, speed walk the distance recording their time, then determine how many days it would take walking at that speed to get to Disney World 1257 miles away.

The students experienced real-world scenarios, collaborated, problem solved and had fun while learning math. Take a look below.

This year the Ronald McDonald House set a goal of raising $90,000. With the help of the 60 schools that participated in the program, they doubled their goal and raised $180,000! More than 225 families next year can stay because of our combined fundraising.
Congratulations to Mia Ralston (5th grade), Daniel Hladik (2nd grade), and Turner Michaud (Kindergarten) for being recognized as top fundraisers!

post_text: The Concert Choir performed at the NYSSMA Ensemble Festival in April at Niskayuna High School.They prepared three Level 6 songs, considered to be the most difficult level by the New York State School Music Association, and were awarded a Gold Medal with Distinction for their efforts. The award is the highest honor given to a high school choir in the state of New York. This accomplishment required an incredible amount of hard work and dedication by all of the students involved. Congratulations to the Concert Choir on this tremendous achievement!Days before, the Schalmont High School Wind Ensemble performed at the NYSSMA Major Ensemble Festival on Monday, April 15, at Shaker High School. They prepared three Level 5 pieces, considered the second highest difficulty by the New York State School Music Association, and they were awarded a Silver Medal for their performance. These students put in hours of practice in order to prepare these difficult, college-level pieces of music. Congratulations to the Wind Ensemble on their achievement!
